Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2027, India has officially entered into a collaborative agreement with another country on a major quantum computing project. A 'major quantum computing project' is defined as a project with a budget exceeding $50 million and involving significant research and development efforts in quantum technologies. The collaboration must be publicly announced by the governments or relevant agencies of both India and the collaborating country. Credible reports from at least three major news organizations (such as BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post, etc.) confirming the collaboration will also suffice for resolution. If the project is canceled or significantly downsized, the question will resolve as No.

Q.title: Will India produce a functional quantum computer that surpasses 100 qubits by 2028?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2028, India has produced a functional quantum computer that is capable of operating with more than 100 qubits. The quantum computer must be publicly demonstrated to perform a quantum algorithm that showcases its capabilities, such as quantum supremacy or a significant computational advantage over classical computers. The demonstration must be reported by at least two reputable sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and must be verified by independent experts in the field of quantum computing. The definition of 'functional' means that the quantum computer can reliably manipulate and measure qubits without significant errors that would undermine its performance.

Q.title: Will Indian universities be ranked among the top 10 in quantum computing research by 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, at least one Indian university is ranked among the top 10 universities globally in quantum computing research according to the QS World University Rankings or the Times Higher Education World University Rankings. P.title: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, credible evidence demonstrates that Microsoft's carbon negative pledge has led to a measurable reduction in global CO2 levels. The reduction must be at least 1% of global CO2 emissions compared to levels recorded in 2020, as reported by authoritative sources such as the Global Carbon Project or the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). The impact must be attributed directly to Microsoft's initiatives and not to other external factors or global events. The evidence must be supported by peer-reviewed research or official reports from reputable organizations (e.g., UN, World Resources Institute) that analyze the effectiveness of corporate carbon pledges on global emissions.

Q.title: Will other major tech companies follow Microsoft's lead in committing to carbon negative pledges by 2025?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, at least three major technology companies (defined as companies with a market capitalization over $10 billion) publicly commit to carbon negative pledges. A carbon negative pledge must include a clear plan to remove more carbon dioxide from the atmosphere than the company emits, with specific targets and timelines outlined. The commitment must be reported in a reputable news source (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) or through an official press release from the company. Companies that have previously made similar commitments without updates or new pledges do not count toward this resolution.

P.title: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?
P.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, South Korea is recognized as the leader in global digital governance based on the following criteria:

- Significant collaborations or partnerships with at least three other countries in establishing global digital standards must be in place, with documented agreements and initiatives.

P.title: Will the World Health Organization declare a global health emergency due to climate-related diseases by 2030?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the World Health Organization (WHO) officially declares a global health emergency specifically related to diseases that are directly attributable to climate change. The declaration must be made in a formal statement or report from the WHO and must identify specific diseases that are exacerbated by climate change, such as vector-borne diseases (e.g., malaria, dengue), respiratory diseases (e.g., asthma, allergies), and waterborne diseases (e.g., cholera). The declaration should be based on scientific evidence and consensus from the global health community, including input from epidemiologists and climate scientists. The resolution will not count declarations that are vague or general in nature without specific reference to climate-related diseases.

Q.title: Will a major country experience a climate-related health crisis that prompts international intervention by 2030?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major country experiences a climate-related health crisis that meets the following criteria and prompts international intervention: 

1. The health crisis must be directly linked to climate change, such as extreme heat events, widespread disease outbreaks exacerbated by climate conditions, or significant food and water shortages due to climate impacts. 
2. The crisis must result in a declaration of a national emergency or similar governmental response indicating the severity of the situation. 
3. International intervention must be initiated, which can include humanitarian aid, medical assistance, or military support from other countries or international organizations (e.g., WHO, UN). 

The resolution will be based on credible reports from at least two major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) confirming the crisis and the international response. In cases where the situation is ambiguous or contested, the resolution will be based on the consensus of health and climate experts as reported in reputable scientific publications.

Q.title: Will a major breakthrough in energy storage technology occur by 2035?
Q.body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2035, a significant breakthrough in energy storage technology is achieved and recognized by the scientific community. A 'major breakthrough' is defined as: 
1. A new energy storage technology that demonstrates at least a 50% improvement in energy density compared to current leading technologies (e.g., lithium-ion batteries), or 
2. A novel technology that enables energy storage at a cost of less than $100 per kWh at scale, or

Q.title: Will a new clean energy technology be adopted by a major country by 2030?
Q.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a major country (defined as a member of the G20) officially adopts a new clean energy technology that significantly reduces greenhouse gas emissions compared to existing technologies. The technology must be recognized by a reputable international body, such as the International Energy Agency (IEA) or the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). Adoption is defined as the technology being implemented in a national policy or program, with measurable targets for deployment. Technologies that are in trial phases or limited to pilot projects do not count towards this resolution. Additionally, the technology must have been developed or significantly improved in the last 10 years to qualify as 'new'.
